instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power.
threads.message:
Hi everyone,

I need some quick advice, please.
The MacBook came in with no power. Trackpad clicking and cycling. It has been opened before, presumably by the customer. The screen shield is missing for both the backlight and LVDS connector. There are no obvious shorts under the thermal camera.
After inspection, I found that the L7210/20/30 has a resistance of 0 ohms, whereas on a good board, it should be 73 ohms. <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL>/3/3 is all dead short with 0 ohms.
I removed the <RESISTOR>R7210</RESISTOR>/20/30 to isolate the CPU, and <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is still dead short. When I inject 0.8V on that line, it draws current, but nothing gets hot under the thermal camera.
Am I correct in saying that the CPU is dead?

The customer is desperate for the data.

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power.
threads.message: Pure short there, means dead CPU...
